<line: 23> I, the complainant in this case, state that the following is true to the best of my knowledge and belief.
<line: 24> On or about the date(s) of
<line: 25> September 29, 2018
<line: 26> in the county of
<line: 27>  Hidalgo
<line: 28> in the
<line: 29> Southern
<line: 30> District of
<line: 31> Texas

[TEXT]
<line: 34> Code Section
<line: 35> Offense Description
<line: 36> 21 USC S 952
<line: 37> Illegal Importation of a Controlled Substance / Approximately 32.32
<line: 38> Kilograms of Methamphetamine..

[TEXT]
<line: 40> This criminal complaint is based on these facts:.

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 7:18-cr-01745  Document1 Filed in TXSD on 09/30/18  Page 2 of 2

[TITLE]
<line: 4> Attachment A

[TEXT]
<line: 6> On September 29, 2018, Homeland Security Investigations (HSI), McAllen, Texas, received a
<line: 7> phone call from Customs and Border Protection Officers (CBPO) at the Pharr, Texas Port of
<line: 8> Entry about a vehicle suspected to be loaded with narcotics. During an x-ray inspection of the
<line: 9> vehicle, anomalies were discovered within the vehicle's seats..

[TEXT]
<line: 11> That vehicle was being driven by Alberto ORTEGA-Lopez, a Mexican national, as he attempted
<line: 12> to make entry into the United States from Mexico..

[TEXT]
<line: 14> During a physical inspection of the vehicle, CBPOs discovered several packages which field-.
<line: 15> tested positive for the characteristics of methamphetamine with a total weight of 32.32
<line: 16> kilograms.

[TEXT]
<line: 18> CBPO Task Force Officer Ana Aguilera and HSI Special Agent Isidro Martinez responded to.
<line: 19> interview ORTEGA-Lopez. During the interview, ORTEGA-Lopez made severaI inconsistent
<line: 20> statements about his travel plans. ORTEGA-Lopez stated he agreed to cross the vehicle
<line: 21> containing what he believed to be an illegal substance into the United States, and deliver it to.
<line: 22> unknown individuals in Houston, Texas in exchange for monetary gain. ORTEGA-Lopez stated
<line: 23> he was to contact an unknown individual in Mexico once he successfully crossed the port of
<line: 24> entry and again after he successfully crossed the United States Border Patrol Checkpoint on his
<line: 25> way to Houston, Texas. ORTEGA-Lopez stated he did not know exactly what he was
<line: 26> transporting, but suspected it was drugs because he was to be paid $700 for such an easy job

[TEXT]
<line: 28> ORTEGA-Lopez admitted to having made similar trips to Houston, Texas in the past and.
<line: 29> delivering the vehicle to unknown individuals in exchange for a $700 payment.
